With that description, I'm even more confident that we're on the right track.

The strong, distinct flavor and amazing aroma are likely due to the combination of aromatics, herbs, and spices. The clear, rich broth suggests that she might have skimmed off any impurities and excess fat during the cooking process, which would have contributed to the clarity and depth of flavor.

And, of course, the tender meat is a testament to her slow-cooking technique. Simmering the soup for an extended period would have broken down the connective tissues in the meat, making it fall-apart tender.

Now, I want to emphasize the importance of taste and adjust as you go. The seasoning blend I provided is just a starting point. As you cook the soup, be sure to taste it regularly and adjust the seasoning to your liking. You might find that you need more or less of certain herbs, or that you want to add other spices to enhance the flavor.

Remember, the goal is to recreate the flavor profile that resonates with you, not to follow a recipe to the letter. Your grandma's recipe is a part of your family's culinary heritage, and it's okay to put your own twist on it.

As you cook, take notes on what you're doing, and don't be afraid to experiment. You can always adjust the seasoning, add or subtract ingredients, and try different techniques to get the flavor just right.

Lastly, I want to encourage you to share your progress with your family and friends. Cooking is a way to connect with others, and sharing your grandma's recipe can help keep her memory alive. Who knows, you might even inspire others to start cooking and sharing their own family recipes!

Good luck, and I hope you'll keep me updated on your progress!
